text: vignette describes process generating gridmap layouts gridmappr. Given set geographic point locations, gridmappr creates grid (stated row, column dimensions) places point grid cell distance points geographic space within grid space minimised. exploring various gridmap arrangements, vignette demonstrates maps can plotted analysis: building polygon file grid layout solutions encode thematic maps showing geographically-arranged charts can created using allocation standard calls ggplot2. gridmappr R implementation Jo Wood’s Observable notebooks Linear Programming solvers application Gridmap Allocation problem.

title: Generating gridmap layouts
text: following libraries required run vignette:
code: library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) library(sf) library(stringr) library(gridmappr)  theme_set(theme_void())

title: Generating gridmap layouts
text: main allocation function gridmappr points_to_grid(). return grid cell positions (row column identifiers) given set geographic locations. paramerised : pts tibble geographic points (x,y) allocated grid. n_row Maximum number rows grid. n_col Maximum number columns grid. compactness Optional parameter 0 1 0 allocates towards edges, 0.5 preserves scaled geographic location 1 allocates towards centre grid. Default 1 (compact cluster). spacers Optional list grid cell locations defining grid location fixed spacers allocated points. Coordinates (row, column) order origin (1,1) bottom-left. Default empty list.

title: Generating gridmap layouts
text: generating gridmap layout 33 London boroughs, try 8x8 regular grid. n_row Set 8 n_col Set 8 compactness Set .6, attempting preserve geographic layout degree compactness around grid centre.  gridmappr allows spacers (light grey) specified: grid cells constrain distribution allowing points allocated . Adding targeted spacers, can get close LondonSquared layout.
code: n_row <- 8 n_col <- 8 pts <- london_boroughs |>   st_drop_geometry() |>   select(area_name, x = easting, y = northing) solution <- points_to_grid(pts, n_row, n_col, compactness = .6) n_row <- 7 n_col <- 8 spacers <- list(   c(1, 3), c(1, 5), c(1, 6),   c(2, 2), c(2, 7),   c(3, 1),   c(6, 1), c(6, 2), c(6, 7), c(6, 8),   c(7, 2), c(7, 3), c(7, 4), c(7, 6), c(7, 7) ) pts <- london_boroughs |>   st_drop_geometry() |>   select(area_name, x = easting, y = northing) solution <- points_to_grid(pts, n_row, n_col, compactness = 1, spacers)

title: Using gridmap layouts
text: travel--work data contains origin-destination pairs representing every borough--borough commute combination: tibble containing 9,801 observations five variables: o_bor Borough origin. d_bor Borough destination. occ_type Occupation type commute: 1_managers_senior, 2_professional, 3_associate_professional, 4_administrative, 5_trade, 6_caring_leisure, 7_sales_customer, 8_machine_operatives, 9_elementary. count Count number commutes occupation type origin-destination borough pair. is_prof Whether occupation type professional non-professional. analyse commuting London boroughs occupation type differentiate : jobs located borough, accessed workers living London; workers living borough, access jobs London
code: london_ttw <- read_csv("london_ttw.csv") # Jobs located in borough. jobs <- london_ttw |>    group_by(d_bor, occ_type) |>    summarise(count=sum(count), is_prof=first(is_prof), type="jobs") |> ungroup() |>    select(type, bor=d_bor, occ_type, is_prof, count) # Workers living in borough. workers <- london_ttw |>    group_by(o_bor, occ_type) |>    summarise(count=sum(count), is_prof=first(is_prof), type="workers") |> ungroup() |>    select(type, bor=o_bor, occ_type, is_prof, count)

title: Using gridmap layouts
text: Since created simple feature object layout make_grid(), straightforward generate thematic gridmaps ggplot2: using geom_sf() alongside ggplot2’s standard geom layers grammar. map encode counts jobs workers borough proportional symbols (geom_point()) facet_grid() plot according two categorical variables: occupation type (collapsed professional non-professional) whether jobs workers borough counted .  quick explanation ggplot2 spec: Data: Counts workers jobs (type) borough, collapsed professional non-professional occupation types (is_prof). Casting is_prof type factor variables gives us control order appear plot. Encoding: proportional symbols positioned centroids borough grid cells (x, y), sized according count jobs workers coloured according occupation type (is_prof). Marks: geom_point() proportional symbols geom_sf() grid outline. Scale: scale_fill/colour_manual() hue-based associating occupation type scale_size()controlling size points encode counts. Facets: facet_wrap() workers/jobs summary type high-level occupation type (is_prof).
code: gridmap |>    inner_join(bind_rows(jobs, workers), by=c("area_name"="bor")) |>    group_by(area_name, is_prof, type) |>    summarise(count=sum(count), x=first(x), y=first(y)) |>    mutate(     is_prof=factor(if_else(is_prof, "professional", "non-professional"), levels=c("professional", "non-professional")),     type=factor(type, levels=c("workers", "jobs"))     ) |>    ggplot(aes(x = x, y = y)) +   geom_sf(fill="#EEEEEE") +   geom_point(aes(size=count, colour=is_prof),  alpha=.3) +   geom_point(aes(size=count, colour=is_prof), fill="transparent", pch=21, stroke=.5) +   facet_grid(is_prof~type) +   scale_fill_manual(values=c("#4d004b", "#00441b"), guide="none") +   scale_colour_manual(values=c("#4d004b", "#00441b"), guide="none")

code: plot_data <- london_ttw |>    group_by(o_bor, d_bor, is_prof) |>    summarise(count=sum(count)) |>    pivot_wider(names_from = is_prof, values_from = count) |>    rename(non_prof = `FALSE`, prof = `TRUE`) |> ungroup() |>    mutate(global_prof=sum(prof)/sum(prof+non_prof))|>    group_by(d_bor) |>    mutate(     count=prof+non_prof+.0001,      obs=prof+.0001,      exp=(global_prof*count),      resid=(obs-exp)/(exp^.7)     ) |> ungroup() bbox_grid <- st_bbox(gridmap) width <- bbox_grid$xmax-bbox_grid$xmin   height <- bbox_grid$ymax-bbox_grid$ymin   range_resid <- max(abs(plot_data$resid))  plot <- plot_data |>    left_join(gridmap |>  st_drop_geometry() |> select(area_name, d_col=col, d_row=row),by=c("d_bor"="area_name")) |>    left_join(gridmap |> select(o_x=x,o_y=y, area_name), by=c("o_bor"="area_name")) |>   mutate(     bor_label=if_else(o_bor==d_bor,d_bor,""),     bor_focus=o_bor==d_bor   ) |> st_as_sf() |>    ggplot()+   geom_sf(aes(fill=resid), colour="#616161", size=0.15, alpha=0.9)+   geom_text(data=plot_data %>% filter(bor_focus),              aes(x=o_x, y=o_y, label=str_extract(o_bor, "^.{1}")),              colour="#252525", alpha=0.9, size=2.1,             hjust="centre", vjust="middle")+   geom_text(data=plot_data %>% filter(bor_focus),              aes(x=bbox_grid$xmax, y=bbox_grid$ymin, label=str_extract(o_bor, "^.{3}")),              colour="#252525", alpha=0.6, size=3.5,             hjust="right", vjust="bottom")+   coord_sf(crs=st_crs(plot_data), datum=NA)+   facet_grid(-d_row~d_col, shrink=FALSE)+   scale_fill_distiller(palette="PRGn", direction=-1, breaks = c(-range_resid, 0, range_resid), labels = c("low prof", "avg", "high prof"), limits = c(-range_resid, range_resid)) +   theme(     panel.spacing=unit(0.1, "lines"),     strip.text.x = element_blank(), strip.text.y = element_blank(),   )

what: Gridmap allocation using compactness with points_to_grid()
title: Gridmap Allocations with Approximate Spatial Arrangements
text: Gridmaps, sometimes called tilemaps, maps spatial units allocated spatially-arranged grid cells regular size. Many gridmaps generated manually, widely used LondonSquared layout London boroughs example. automatic allocation spatial units grid cells, various constraints might considered, see Meulemans et al. 2017 formal discussion evaluation. gridmappr allocates geographic point locations grid cells total squared distances geographic grid locations minimised. point allocated one grid cell cell grid can contain one geographic point. grid must therefore contain least many cells geographic points. allocation optimised compactness parameter, scaled 0-1. value 0.5 attempts place point relative geographic position scaled within bounds grid; value 1 attempts place point close centre grid possible; compactness closer 0 allocates cells increasingly towards edge grid. main allocation function call points_to_grid(). return grid cell positions (row column identifiers) given set geographic locations. paramerised : pts tibble geographic points (x,y) allocated grid. n_row Maximum number rows grid. n_col Maximum number columns grid. compactness Optional parameter 0 1 0 allocates towards edges, 0.5 preserves scaled geographic location 1 allocates towards centre grid. Default 1 (compact cluster). spacers Optional list grid cell locations defining grid location fixed spacers allocated points. Coordinates (row, column) order origin (1,1) bottom-left. Default empty list.
